subject: Add plug-in mechanism to swift-init
commit_message:
Add plug-in mechanism to swift-init

While the plug-in layer for the Swift backend storage processes is being
finalized, intermediate efforts have generally supplanted the top level
executable scripts with custom implementations that will typically deviate
only slightly from the stock implementation.  This approach is both flexible
and effective; however, because it is not well defined it has a side effect of
being incompatible with swift-init.

The optional command line argument --plugin-command-prefix for swift-init will
make it possible for swift-init to manage alternative top level Swift server
executable scripts which are compatible with the stock Swift processes by
appending an alternative prefix to the name of launched script.

For example, if you install an alternative swift-object-replicator
implementation at 'mybackend-object-replicator' you can start the process from
the command line using swift-init's config and pid management with the
command:

    swift-init -p mybackend object-replicator start

subject: Fixes all issues of tempest caused by async network allocation
commit_message:
Fixes all issues of tempest caused by async network allocation

Nova uses NetworkInfoAsyncWrapper to alloc network in an
async manner, and this allows one to start querying for
network info before you know you will need it. Nova will
invokes refresh_cache method to update instance_cache_info
after excuting the allocate_for_instance method as well.

But nova rest api will query allocate_for_instance table
directly, thus we will get the empty network info before
instance_cache_info table has been updated asynchronously.
The result is not deterministic,
but in the end the instance_info_cache will be consistent.

The patch will check network info in the method
wait_for_server_status to fix this issues.

subject: Support EC2 API wildcards for DescribeTags filters
commit_message:
Support EC2 API wildcards for DescribeTags filters

The EC2 API supports glob-style wildcards in filters.

From http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ApiReference-query-DescribeTags.html:

"You can use wildcards in a filter value. An asterisk (*) matches zero or more characters, and
a question mark (?) matches exactly one character. You can escape special characters using a
backslash (\) before the character. For example, a value of \*amazon\?\\ searches for the literal

subject: Migrate to pbr for build

Migrate to pbr for build

pbr is the libification of what was openstack.common.setup. If provides
the build information in a delcarative form, instead of as executable python
code, which works around the chicken and egg problem of needing setup
libraries present to run setup, but needing to run setup to tell if you
need setup libraries.

One of the features that comes along with this is versioning based on
git tags. If the current revision is a signed git tag, then that is the
version of the package. If it is not, the version is equal to the most
recent git tag, plus a commit count, plus a git sha (similar to git
describe, but scrubbed for python version rules compliance)

pbr updates are also part of the upcoming automation around ensuring
global requirements stay in sync.

Make bandwidth allocation visible to scheduler

The scheduler and the compute nodes currently keep track of disk,
memory and vcpu resource allocation. This includes reporting available
and allocated resource values, accounting for their consumption in the
scheduler's HostState class and gating acceptance of new instances at
the compute node in the Claims and ResourceTracker classes. It should

are not dynamic resource utilization metrics.

Network bandwidth is added to this list to allow the scheduler to be
